case_name: J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Ltd. v. Sales Tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 857 of 1964 filed by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated April 27, 1964 in Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 2367 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 857 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1964, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 2367 of 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah J. Messrs J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Ltd. is a public limited Company having its registered office at Kanpur.

facts.text: J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Ltd. is a public limited company with registered office at Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Ltd. is a public limited Company having its registered office at Kanpur. The Company manufactures for sale companyton textiles, tiles and other companymodities.

facts.text: The Company manufactures for sale cotton textiles, tiles and other commodities.

anchor.surface_text: The Company manufactures for sale companyton textiles, tiles and other companymodities. The Company applied on June 21, 1957, requesting the Sales Tax Officer, Sector II, Kanpur, to register it as a dealer under S. 7 1  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956,

facts.text: Company applied on June 21, 1957 to Sales Tax Officer, Sector II, Kanpur for registration under Section 7(1) of Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Company applied on June 21, 1957, requesting the Sales Tax Officer, Sector II, Kanpur, to register it as a dealer under S. 7 1  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, and prayed that the following goods which it ordinarily purchased in the companyrse of inter-State trade may be specified in the certificate Cotton staple fibre, yam, wastes, companyl, petrol, machinery, electricals, spares, hardwares, dyes and companyours, chemicals, auxiliaries, oils, lubricants, tallows, starches, woollen clothings, gums, clays, salt, beltings, bobbins, shuttles, wooden accessories and other mill stores for manufacturing cloth, yarn, tiles and paints etc.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer granted the certificate of registration as prayed, specifying listed goods including cotton staple fibre, yarn, wastes, coal, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer granted the certificate as prayed. The certificate of registration was later modified and the following additional categories of goods were specified Industrial gases, drawing instruments, photographic materials, packing materials including wood, paper, straw and card-boards etc. and building materials including iron, steel, cement, lime, fire bricks and refrac- tories.

facts.text: Certificate of registration later modified to include additional goods: industrial gases, drawing instruments, photographic materials, packing materials, building materials including iron, steel, cement, lime, fire bricks, refractories.

anchor.surface_text: The certificate of registration was later modified and the following additional categories of goods were specified Industrial gases, drawing instruments, photographic materials, packing materials including wood, paper, straw and card-boards etc. and building materials including iron, steel, cement, lime, fire bricks and refrac- tories. Thereafter by numberice dated July 19, 1961, the Sales Tax Officer cancelled the specification in respect of companyl

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer by notice dated July 19, 1961 cancelled specification of coal and called upon Company to show cause why certificate be amended to exclude drawing instruments, photographic materials, building materials including iron, steel, cement, lime and electricals.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter by numberice dated July 19, 1961, the Sales Tax Officer cancelled the specification in respect of companyl and called upon the Company to show cause why the certificate of registration be number amended so as to exclude therefrom drawing instruments, photographic materials, building materials including iron, steel, cement and lime and certain goods companyered under the term electricals.

facts.text: Company showed cause against the notice contending all articles specified were required in manufacture and processing of goods for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The Company showed cause against the numberice and companytended that all the articles specified in the certificate were required in the manufacture and processing of goods for sale.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer by order dated August 9, 1962 directed deletion from registration certificate of: drawing material, photographic material, building material including lime and cement except cement used in manufacture of tiles for re-sale, electricals, iron and steel and coal.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated August 9, 1962 the Sales Tax Officer directed that from the registration certificate the following items be deleted Drawing material, photographic material, building material including lime and cement  except cement used in manufacture of tiles for re-sale , electricals. iron and steel and companyl, and called upon the Company to surrender the certificate of registration within three days for making the proposed amendments.

facts.text: Company applied to Allahabad High Court for writ of certiorari quashing STO order dated August 9, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Company then applied to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad for a writ of certiorari calling for the record of the case and quashing the order dated August 9, 1962.

facts.text: In High Court, counsel for Company did not press petition in respect of iron, steel and coal.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, companynsel for the Company did number press the petition in respect of iron, steel and companyl.

facts.text: Company submitted that remaining items covered by s.8(3)(b) of Central Sales Tax Act read with Rule 13.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company submitted that the remaining items were companyered by s. 8 3  b  of the Central Sales Tax Act read with Rule 13 framed under s. 13 of the Act, and on that account the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer was illegal

facts.text: Allahabad High Court rejected the writ petition holding drawing instruments, photographic materials, colours, chemicals, electricals, machinery and building materials such as cement, lime not comprehended in s.8(3)(b) read with Rule 13.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived the companytention of the Company that the Sales Tax Officer had numberjurisdiction to revise the certificate of registration issued after due enquiry, and rejected the petition holding that drawing instruments, photographic materials, companyours, chemicals, electricals, machinery and building materials such as cement, lime are number companyprehended in the expression in the manufacture or processing of goods for sale within the meaning of S. 8  3    b  read with Rule

facts.text: Company appealed to Supreme Court against High Court order dismissing petition.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order dismissing the petition, the Company has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Counsel for Company did not raise contention that STO had no jurisdiction to modify certificate.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company has very properly number sought to raise the companytention that the Sales Tax Officer had numberjurisdiction to modify the certificate of registration, merely because the certificate as originally granted was issued after due enquiry.

facts.text: STO order did not delete machinery, colours and chemicals from certificate.

anchor.surface_text: By the order of the Sales Tax Officer machinery, and companyours and chemicals were number deleted from the certificate, and the exclusion of building materials, cement and lime was expressly restricted so that it was number to operate in respect of cement used in manufacture of tiles for sale.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds drawing and photographic materials intended for use as equipment in designing process which is integral to manufacture.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyfirmed the exclusion of drawing and photographic materials on the ground that those materials are required merely in the preparation of designs which though necessary for turning out textile goods cannot be said to be goods intended for use in the manufacture of goods.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order and directs modification of STO order by deleting drawing materials, photographic materials and electricals from deletions.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic materials and electricals. The rest of the order of the Sales Tax Officer will stand.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds exclusion of building materials including lime and cement (except for tiles) as not qualifying under Rule 13.

anchor.surface_text: Building materials including lime and cement number required in the manufacture of tiles for sale cannot, however, be regarded within the meaning of Rule 13, as raw materials in the manufacture or processing of goods or even as plant.

facts.text: Electricals qualify as equipment necessary for manufacturing process in cotton textile factory.

anchor.surface_text: The expression electricals is somewhat vague. But in a factory manufacturing companyton and other textiles, certain electrical equipment in the present stage of development would be companymercially necessary.

facts.text: Company has substantially succeeded.

anchor.surface_text: The Company has substantially succeeded.

issues.text: Whether the Sales Tax Officer had jurisdiction to amend the registration certificate under S.7(4) for sufficient reason including erroneous inclusion of articles not covered by s.8(3)(b)?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company has very properly not sought to raise the contention that the Sales Tax Officer had no jurisdiction to modify the certificate of registration, merely because the certificate as originally granted was issued after due enquiry. Under S. 7  4  of the Act a certificate of registration granted under s. 7 1  may be cancelled by the authority granting it, inter alia, for any sufficient reason. If on account of some error, the certificate specifies articles which did number fall within the terms of s. 8  3   b  read with Rule 13, the error would manifestly be sufficient reason within the meaning of S. 7  4  a uthorising the cancellation of the certificate qua the items which were erroneously included.

issues.text: Whether the High Court could expand the scope of the writ petition to deal with and reject claims for goods not ordered to be deleted by the Sales Tax Officer such as colours, chemicals and machinery?

anchor.surface_text: In the first instance, it must be pointed out that the High- Court has, in rejecting the petition, dealt with certain matters which were never in issue between the Company and the Sales Tax Officer. By the order of the Sales Tax Officer machinery, and companyours and chemicals were number deleted from the certificate, and the exclusion of building materials, cement and lime was expressly restricted so that it was number to operate in respect of cement used in manufacture of tiles for sale.

issues.text: Whether drawing instruments and photographic materials qualify as goods intended for use as equipment in an integrally related process (designing) under s.8(3)(b) read with Rule 13?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court confirmed the exclusion of drawing and photographic materials on the ground that those materials are required merely in the preparation of designs which though necessary for turning out textile goods cannot be said to be goods intended for use

issues.text: Whether building materials including lime and cement (except cement for tiles manufacture) qualify under s.8(3)(b) read with Rule 13 as raw materials, plant or equipment in the manufacture or processing of goods for sale?

anchor.surface_text: Building materials including lime and cement number required in the manufacture of tiles for sale cannot, however, be regarded within the meaning of Rule 13, as raw materials in the manufacture or processing of goods or even as plant. It is true that buildings must be companystructed for housing the factory in which machinery is installed.

issues.text: Whether 'electricals' qualify under Rule 13 as equipment necessary in the manufacture or processing of goods for sale in normal industry conditions?

anchor.surface_text: The expression electricals is somewhat vague. But in a factory manufacturing companyton and other textiles, certain electrical equipment in the present stage of development would be commercially necessary.

arguments.court_reasoning: Upheld for building/iron/steel/coal; reversed for drawing/photo/electricals

holdings.text: The Sales Tax Officer had jurisdiction to modify the certificate of registration under S.7(4) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 for sufficient reason, including erroneous inclusion of articles not covered by s.8(3)(b) read with Rule 13.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company has very properly not sought to raise the contention that the Sales Tax Officer had no jurisdiction to modify the certificate of registration, merely because the certificate as originally granted was issued after due enquiry. Under S. 7  4  of the Act a certificate of registration granted under s. 7 1  may be cancelled by the authority granting it, inter alia, for any sufficient reason.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of S.7(4): sufficient reason includes error in specifying ineligible articles; original enquiry does not bar amendment.

holdings.text: The High Court exceeded the scope of the writ petition by rejecting claims for goods not ordered deleted by the Sales Tax Officer, such as machinery, colours and chemicals.

anchor.surface_text: In the first instance, it must be pointed out that the High- Court has, in rejecting the petition, dealt with certain matters which were never in issue between the Company and the Sales Tax Officer. By the order of the Sales Tax Officer machinery, and colours and chemicals were not deleted from the certificate, and the exclusion of building materials, cement and lime was expressly restricted so that it was not to operate in respect of cement used in manufacture of tiles for sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural: writ challenge limited to STO's order; High Court cannot expand to non-issued items.

holdings.text: Goods qualify under s.8(3)(b) read with Rule 13 if intended for use in a process or activity so integrally related to the ultimate manufacture that without it, manufacture would be commercially inexpedient.

anchor.surface_text: Where any particular process is so integrally connected with the ultimate production of goods that but for that process, manufacture or processing of goods would be commercially inexpedient, goods required in that process would, in our judgment, fall within the expression in the manufacture of goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and harmonious construction of Rule 13's broad categories (equipment, tools etc.); rejects narrow 'ingredient/directly needed' view; analogies to textile processes and vehicles.

holdings.text: Drawing instruments and photographic materials qualify under Rule 13 as equipment used in the designing process, which is integrally connected to the manufacture of textiles.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rightly pointed out that unless designs are prepared it would be impossible for the workmen to turn out goods for sale. If the process of designing is so intimately connected with the process of manufacture of cloth, we see no reason to regard the process of designing as not being a part of the process of manufacture within the meaning of Rule 13 read with s. 8(3)(b).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies integral process test: designing essential for commercial production of uniform patterns; directly related to production.

holdings.text: Building materials including lime and cement (except those required for tiles manufacture) do not qualify under Rule 13 as raw materials, processing materials or plant in the manufacture of goods.

anchor.surface_text: Building materials including lime and cement not required in the manufacture of tiles for sale cannot, however, be regarded within the meaning of Rule 13, as raw materials in the manufacture or processing of goods or even as plant. It is true that buildings must be constructed for housing the factory in which machinery is installed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: building materials used to construct plant, not as plant/equipment/raw materials in manufacturing process itself.

holdings.text: Electricals qualify under Rule 13 as equipment commercially necessary for manufacturing textiles (e.g., lighting, humidifiers, exhaust fans), provided directly connected to process and not mere office equipment.

anchor.surface_text: The expression electricals is somewhat vague. But in a factory manufacturing cotton and other textiles, certain electrical equipment in the present stage of development would be commercially necessary. For instance, without electric lighting it would be very difficult to carry on the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies integral process test and normal industry conditions: essential for effective manufacturing, not just facilitation.

holdings.text: The STO's order dated August 9, 1962 is modified by excluding deletions of drawing materials, photographic materials and electricals; upheld as to building materials, iron, steel and coal.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic materials and electricals. The rest of the order of the Sales Tax Officer will stand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of holdings h3-h6 to specific facts; partly reverses STO/High Court.

precedents.citation: Indian Copper Corporation Ltd v. Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Bihar and Ors 1

anchor.surface_text: Indian Copper Corporation Ltd v. Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Bihar and Ors 1

precedents.case_name: Indian Copper Corporation Ltd v. Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Bihar and Ors
precedents.cited_proposition: vehicles used by a Company which mined ore and turned out copper in carrying on activities as a miner and as a manufacturer fell within Rule 13, even if the vehicles were used merely for removing ore from the mine to the factory, and finished goods from the factory to the place of storage. Spare parts and accessories required for the effective operation of those vehicles were also held to fall within Rule 13

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company has very properly not sought to raise the contention that the Sales Tax Officer had no jurisdiction to modify the certificate of registration, merely because the certificate as originally granted was issued after due enquiry. Under S. 7  4  of the Act a certificate of registration granted under s. 7 1  may be cancelled by the authority granting it, inter alia, for any sufficient reason.

We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic mate

anchor.surface_text: under s. 7 1  may be cancelled by the authority granting it, inter alia, for any sufficient reason. If on account of some error, the certificate spec

edges.explanation: The holding directly answers the issue by finding that the High Court exceeded the scope of the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: In the first instance, it must be pointed out that the High- Court has, in rejecting the petition, dealt with certain matters which were never in issue between the Company and the Sales Tax Officer. By the order of the Sales Tax Officer machinery, and colours and chemicals were not deleted from the certificate, and the exclusion of building materials, cement and lime was expressly restricted so that it was not to operate in respect of cement used in manufacture of tiles for sale.

We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic mate
in carrying on activities as a miner and as a manufacturer  fell within Rule 13, even if the vehicles were used merely for removing ore from the mine

edges.explanation: Holding sets out integral process test addressing the issue of correct test under Rule 13

anchor.surface_text: Where any particular process is so integrally connected with the ultimate production of goods that but for that process, manufacture or processing of goods would be commercially inexpedient, goods required in that process would, in our judgment, fall within the expression in the manufacture of goods.

We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic mate

edges.explanation: Holding that drawing materials qualify supports Rule 13

anchor.surface_text: we see numberreason to regard the process of designing as number being a part of the process of manufacture within the meaning of Rule 13 read with s.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 directly resolves the issue i3 on qualification of drawing instruments and photographic materials under the provision.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rightly pointed out that unless designs are prepared it would be impossible for the workmen to turn out goods for sale. If the process of designing is so intimately connected with the process of manufacture of cloth, we see no reason to regard the process of designing as not being a part of the process of manufacture within the meaning of Rule 13 read with s. 8(3)(b).

We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic mate

edges.explanation: Holding clarifying what does not qualify supports proper application of Rule 13

anchor.surface_text: Building materials including lime and cement not required in the manufacture of tiles for sale cannot, however, be regarded within the meaning of Rule 13, as raw materials in the manufacture or processing of goods or even as plant. It is true that buildings must be constructed for housing the factory in which machinery is installed.

We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic mate

edges.explanation: Holding that electricals qualify supports Rule 13

anchor.surface_text: The expression electricals is somewhat vague. But in a factory manufacturing cotton and other textiles, certain electrical equipment in the present stage of development would be commercially necessary. For instance, without electric lighting it would be very difficult to carry on the business.

We therefore set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer be modified by deleting from paragraph-4 of the order the words drawing materials, photographic mate
